thread.title: Cubs believe they are cusp of eclipsing Cardinals' division dominance
thread.title_full: Cubs believe they are cusp of eclipsing Cardinals' division dominance - Chicago Tribune

author: Mark Gonzales
title: Cubs believe they are cusp of eclipsing Cardinals' division dominance
text:
With the confidence of a nine-game winning streak after they blew away a dark cloud with four victories in their last six games against the rival Cardinals last month, the Cubs sense their goal to seize control of the National League Central is attainable.
"Of course we're ready for some kind of a changing of the guard," manager Joe Maddon said Thursday on the eve of the best-of-five National League Division Series opener at Busch Stadium.
"But I don't expect the Cardinals to go away."
Despite losing several key players to injuries, the Cardinals won a major-league high 100 games, and manager Mike Matheny said the four-day rest between the regular season and playoffs "was well-timed for us."
For the Cubs, a division series victory would bolster their presence in the division that faded significantly after they won division titles in 2007-08.
A victory Friday would give the Cubs triumphs against all of their four division foes — the Reds, Brewers, Pirates and Cardinals — on the road in an eight--game span.
But the division series stakes are greater, and the Cubs will need timely contributions against John Lackey, who is 2-0 with a 1.25 ERA in three starts against them this season.
"It's not like it's getting to the point where you say, 'Who is going to do it tonight?'" Anthony Rizzo said. "You just expect it. I wouldn't say it's a surprise if Addison (Russell) goes deep Friday or someone goes deep that (usually) doesn't, because it has been going on all year that someone steps up and helps carry the load."
This marks the first playoff start for Jon Lester as a Cub, and he laughed when he discovered he will be facing Lackey, a teammate and friend from their days with the Red Sox.
"That's my boy," Lackey said.
Said Lester: "It's not too often you get to be in a situation like this to go against one of your better friends. But, come (Friday), we're not buddies anymore."
Cubs catcher David Ross also played with Lackey and Lester on the Red Sox and called them "big rednecks, and I love them both."
Lackey (13-10), 36, is expected to attract mild interest this winter from the Cubs, who are in the market to add impact pitching.
"Aces are special, but they don't grow on trees," Ross said. "But there are number of things that make up an ace, and personality is one of them."
Lackey has the distinction of pitching World Series-clinching games for the Angels (2002) and the Red Sox (2013).
Lester is 6-4 in 14 postseason starts with a 2.57 ERA, and is 2-0 in the World Series. Lackey is 7-5 in 21 playoff appearances with a 3.08 ERA, including a 2-1 record in the World Series.
"Experience wires guys," Ross said. "You get wired, your personality comes out with the more experience you have. I don't think Jon Lester is the same guy on the mound that he was as a rookie or three years in. You mature and learn from your experiences and you grow as players.
"Our team is a huge example of that. This team is not the same team that we broke camp with and was playing in May. It's a totally different team and a mature team with very experienced people."
Maddon pointed to the Cubs' win-or-go-home triumph Wednesday night in Pittsburgh in the NL wild-card game as their latest step in their maturity and development.
"When you go through a moment like we did (in a 4-0 victory), we played Game 7 already," Maddon said. "You go through that moment where you have to win to advance."
Rookie Kris Bryant doesn't anticipate the pressure of the NLDS equaling what he experienced Wednesday.
"This is my first taste of postseason baseball," Bryant said. "I don't know what to expect, but I'm ready for anything."
